results.title: Jacqueline du Pre
results.brief_description: Jacqueline du Pre, a sixteen year old girl who was a pupil of Pablo Casals and described by critics as one of the world’s greatest cellists. Accompanied by Iris du Pre on the piano, she plays ‘Song Without Words’ Opus 109 by Mendelsohn, ‘Intermezzo’ from ‘Goyescas’ by Granados and ‘Allegro Appassionato’ by Saint-Saens. Presented by Patricia Foy.

results.title: Jacob: 'Everybody's allowed to cry'
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Australian Film Commission and Lyn Bugden
results.brief_description: A moving documentation of the life of a small boy about to face his sixth major operation in six years. Raises questions of care for the hospitalised, the rights of the patient and family, and the emotional requirements of people reliant on technology for life support. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Jacob's ladder
results.creator_credit: Carolco Pictures, Alan Marshall and Adrian Lyne
results.brief_description: Jacob Singer is a Vietnam veteran working as a postman who is deeply haunted by a horrible experience in battle, the details of which he cannot clearly recall. When strange and violent hallucinations begin to invade his everyday life, together with the discovery that his fellow battalion members are also seeing the same demons, he begins to suspect covert Army involvement. As the visions become darker and more terrifying, he suffers severe panic attacks related to the chaos that may be reality or that may merely exist in his own mind. Cast includes: Tim Robbins, Elizabeth Pena, Danny Aiello, Matt Craven, Pruitt Taylor Vince and Jason Alexander.

results.title: Jacob's dream
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Alan Madden
results.brief_description: In both his sleeping and waking hours, Jacob encounters a character who provides the basis for the script of his short film; an assessment panel is not impressed. Cast includes John Penman, Bryon Williams, Edward Rosser, John Phillips, Taylor Owynns. Cinematography by Peter Tammer. Music composed and conducted by Christopher Gordon.

results.title: Jacky visits the zoo
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Richard Gilbert and Mort Ransen
results.brief_description: A tour of the zoo is given considerable momentum as an irate keeper chases Jacky for teasing the animals. The camera catches good close-ups of the zoo’s polar bear, lion, giraffe, elephant, rhinoceros, camel, zebra and finally Jacky, in a cage labelled “Wild Boy.” Piano soundtrack, no dialogue. (Award: Rome)

results.title: Jacks or better
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, George Johnson, John Taylor, Raymond Hall and David Geddes
results.brief_description: Artist Char Davies’ vision of logging expressed in images celebrating the magnificence of the British Columbia forest. This film challenges the myth that stereotypes loggers as insensitive to the act of felling trees. It leaves its audience mindful of deforestation and of our responsibility to it as a living natural resource.

results.title: Jackpine journey
results.creator_credit: Associated Screen Studios, Canadian Pacific Railway and Earl Clark
results.brief_description: A CPR steam train speeds through northern forest intercut with the story of vacationists enjoying nature. Scenes of: men canoeing along Ontario waterways, installing campsites, and fishing; spectacular scenery, especially near rapids and falls; and all types of wildlife. Narrated by Peel Stevens.

results.title: Jacka V.C.: a film by Nigel Buesst and Ross Cooper
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Australian Film Commission, Ross Cooper, Nigel Buesst and Sunrise Picture Company
results.brief_description: Albert Jacka was raised in the bush, won Australia’s first VC at Gallipoli, and went on to become the epitome of the Australian front line fighting soldier. No man better personified the archetypical Australian of the early decades of the century. His heroic feats captured the imagination of a generation, yet, today Albert Jacka is almost forgotten. This film is not only his life story but also an insight into Australian identity and history through archival footage.
results.title_for_label: Jacka V.C.: a film by Nigel Buesst and Ross Cooper

results.title: Jack the Ripper: the final solution
results.creator_credit: R W B Productions, Jeremiah Downing and Gary Rhodes
results.brief_description: Will one of the most mysterious crimes perpetrated by a notorious unknown serial killer ever be solved? Who was Jack the Ripper and why did the killings end with the fifth victim? All will be revealed in this documentary - or will it? Based on Stephen Knight’s book of the same title, Ray McGregor travelled to London, to Whitechapel, where the infamous murders took place and managed to obtain an interview with the author himself. Many theories exist about who Jack the Ripper was and why his victims were all women prostitutes. Stephen Knight in his book and in this interview attempts to dispel the myths and put forward factual evidence. It would appear that the five victims were all women in their 40’s, living in extremely harsh conditions and working as prostitutes. The victims were: Mary Anne Nichols murdered on 31 August 1888, Anne Chapman murdered on 8 September 1888, Elizabeth Stride and Catherine Eddowes murdered on 29/30 September 1888 and Marie Kelly murdered on 9 November 1888. Queen Victoria expressed deep concern to the Prime Minister at the time of the first murder and the Royal link is explored even further by Stephen Knight. Includes still photographs, drawings and newspaper articles of the time.

results.title: Jack the Ripper
results.creator_credit: Thames Television, Euston Films and David Wickes
results.brief_description: Aired approximately 100 years after Jack the Ripper terrified London by killing 5 women, this British production made for television states it has discovered the real identity of the Ripper through extensive research by the director - namely based on top secret files from the Home Office, and interviews with leading criminologist and Scotland Yard officials. Heading the investigation is recovering alcoholic Inspector Frank Abberline (Michael Caine in a Golden Globe award winning performance), ably assisted by Sergeant Godley (Lewis Collins), and with a psychological profile provided by Sir William Gull, an authority on madness, and one of the Queen’s advisors. Heading the list of suspects is American stage actor Richard Mansfield (Armand Assante), the forensic medical examiner Doctor Llewellyn (Michael Hughes), Mr Lees (Ken Bones) - the Queen’s psychic adviser, Sir William’s son-in-law, Doctor Acland (Richard Morant), and social agitator George Lusk (Michael Gothard). Beginning with the first murder of Mary Anne Nicholls in Whitechapel, Abberline breaks through the resistance of the powers that be to try and unmask the Ripper and administer justice. Cast also includes Ray McAnally and Jane Seymour.
